title: added retired.txt
Bump pyyaml from 5.1 to 5.4 in /spot-ingest
body:
Bumps [pyyaml](https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml) from 5.1 to 5.4.
Changelog

Sourced from pyyaml's changelog.

5.4 (2021-01-19)

  • yaml/pyyaml#407 -- Build modernization, remove distutils, fix metadata, build wheels, CI to GHA
  • yaml/pyyaml#472 -- Fix for CVE-2020-14343, moves arbitrary python tags to UnsafeLoader
  • yaml/pyyaml#441 -- Fix memory leak in implicit resolver setup
  • yaml/pyyaml#392 -- Fix py2 copy support for timezone objects
  • yaml/pyyaml#378 -- Fix compatibility with Jython

5.3.1 (2020-03-18)

  • yaml/pyyaml#386 -- Prevents arbitrary code execution during python/object/new constructor

5.3 (2020-01-06)

  • yaml/pyyaml#290 -- Use is instead of equality for comparing with None
  • yaml/pyyaml#270 -- Fix typos and stylistic nit
  • yaml/pyyaml#309 -- Fix up small typo
  • yaml/pyyaml#161 -- Fix handling of slots
  • yaml/pyyaml#358 -- Allow calling add_multi_constructor with None
  • yaml/pyyaml#285 -- Add use of safe_load() function in README
  • yaml/pyyaml#351 -- Fix reader for Unicode code points over 0xFFFF
  • yaml/pyyaml#360 -- Enable certain unicode tests when maxunicode not > 0xffff
  • yaml/pyyaml#359 -- Use full_load in yaml-highlight example
  • yaml/pyyaml#244 -- Document that PyYAML is implemented with Cython
  • yaml/pyyaml#329 -- Fix for Python 3.10
  • yaml/pyyaml#310 -- Increase size of index, line, and column fields
  • yaml/pyyaml#260 -- Remove some unused imports
  • yaml/pyyaml#163 -- Create timezone-aware datetimes when parsed as such
  • yaml/pyyaml#363 -- Add tests for timezone

5.2 (2019-12-02)

  • Repair incompatibilities introduced with 5.1. The default Loader was changed, but several methods like add_constructor still used the old default yaml/pyyaml#279 -- A more flexible fix for custom tag constructors yaml/pyyaml#287 -- Change default loader for yaml.add_constructor yaml/pyyaml#305 -- Change default loader for add_implicit_resolver, add_path_resolver
  • Make FullLoader safer by removing python/object/apply from the default FullLoader yaml/pyyaml#347 -- Move constructor for object/apply to UnsafeConstructor
  • Fix bug introduced in 5.1 where quoting went wrong on systems with sys.maxunicode <= 0xffff yaml/pyyaml#276 -- Fix logic for quoting special characters
  • Other PRs: yaml/pyyaml#280 -- Update CHANGES for 5.1

5.1.2 (2019-07-30)

  • Re-release of 5.1 with regenerated Cython sources to build properly for Python 3.8b2+

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 58d0cb7 5.4 release
  • a60f7a1 Fix compatibility with Jython
  • ee98abd Run CI on PR base branch changes
  • ddf2033 constructor.timezone: _copy & deepcopy
  • fc914d5 Avoid repeatedly appending to yaml_implicit_resolvers
  • a001f27 Fix for CVE-2020-14343
  • fe15062 Add 3.9 to appveyor file for completeness sake
  • 1e1c7fb Add a newline character to end of pyproject.toml
  • 0b6b7d6 Start sentences and phrases for capital letters
  • c976915 Shell code improvements
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=pyyaml&package-manager=pip&previous-version=5.1&new-version=5.4)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

title: Update website copyrights and scanning config
body:
- Updated all 2020 copyrights to 2021
- Added the .asf.yaml file so that our website publishing works properly again (https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/INFRA/Git+-+.asf.yaml+features#Git.asf.yamlfeatures-WebSiteDeploymentServiceforGitRepositories)

We should also look at creating an asf-staging branch we can make changes on first and validate before we publish to asf-site.

title: SPOT-299 Asf site whimsy fixes
body: In SPOT-299, we were trying to add the required ASF site to the home page.  However, after we reviewed the Whimsy logs, it is not enough for links to be available on the home page, the html must actually regex the links.  After reviewing other ASF projects, we found out that Livy had a drop-down menu like ours, that was easily adapted to our needs.  Thus, this change fulfills the intention of SPOT-299 and complies with ASF regulations.

title: Add SSL argument to Impala shell
body:
Resolves SPOT-308.  This just appends ssl on the end of the impala shell command.  This runs without the ca_cert argument, which I think should be fine in most cases.

I didn't update beeline since the spot.conf sort of implies that the JDBC connection string should include kerberos and ssl arguments before hand.  I also ignored the Hive shell, but we should just think about deprecating that whole piece of the code anyway since beeline is more widely supported to connect to Hive.

We should also probably revisit just rewriting this whole thing as a python interface at some point so that we're not maintaining so many versions of the same commands, ddls, etc.

title: Asf site -removed abandoned cruft left over from WordPress
body:
This removes the abandoned/migrated blog posts that are no longer referenced anywhere.

Their removal allows me to more effectively look for unreferenced files in other directories.

title: (SPOT-286) Do not call org.apache.spark.sql.functions.broadcast() on …
body:
…large sets

https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/SPOT/issues/SPOT-286
identifies an issue with calling org.apache.spark.sql.functions.broadcast()
on large datasets which may exceed a limit and cause an exception.

It was determined wrapping a dataset in this way is a performance
optimization, and the justification for this optimization is not clear.

It was decided it was preferable to undo the optimization than allow
it to fail for some situations.

title: Update DATA_SAMPLE.md
body: updated link to sample dns data and data size

title: updated nfdump install instructions to reflect newer version of automake
Spot 301 fix typo to pysparkstreaming
body: Fix a missing typo in text instructions, as per Spot-301

title: Spot 304 fix inconsistencies between hive and avro
body: In two instances, Avro files are created with internal schema where one of the fields "ibyt" was mis-spelled "ibytt".  This corrects that.

title: Asf site updates to install instructions and copyright
add Apache Foundation links on supporting apache page
Spot 298 document odm on spot website
body: Resolves [SPOT-298](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-298).  The Open Data Models (ODM) documentation has been added to the Open Data Models page on the Spot website with some redundancies removed.  There's also some previous merges with the new copyrights included in this PR in order to avoid merge conflicts later on.

title: Spot 296 update copyright year in master
body: Resolves [SPOT-296](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-296).  There were some dependency copyrights in the LICENSE file that needed updating to 2020 as well as the NOTICE file.

title: Spot 297 update remaining website copyright years
body: Resolves [SPOT-297](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-297).  The root index.html and a few other files still had a 2016 reference, and the 2019 references also needed updating to 2020.

title: [SPOT-291] Update Spot Website Copyright to 2018
body:
Updated Copyrights from 2016 to 2018.

Also improved the page-massedit python tool a bit:
- root directory is now dynamic instead of hard-coded
- added substitute feature.

title: [SPOT-287] Fix sudo command, add help, fix ShellCheck warnings
body:
While testing a test system for Spot, I ran into some issues with `hdfs_setup.sh` script. So here is few fixes:
- Fixed command execution using `sudo`
- add `-h | --help` params to the script
- hive command support sudo
- ShellCheck now only warn about the source line.

Tested on CentOS7, cloudera 6.0.0 using hive as database.

title: Spot 181 odm
body:
./ml_ops.sh 20181102 flow 5000 0.5
The order of the two parameters needs to be changed.

title: SPOT-279 - Inconsistencies in the open data model descriptions
body:
There are some inconsistencies in the open data model descriptions:

* There are long and bigint types for timestamps.
* Ipv4 addresses are declared as long but int is enough.
* Ipv6 addresses are declared as bigint.
* http info status are explicitly declared as http_info_status when it is just a specific case of http_code_status.

Here is a modified version of the open data model trying to fix the previous inconsitencies. Following avro types I have used:

* int for 32bit
* long for 64bit.
* Avro does not have a type for 128bit. I have use int128 as type definition for the ODM. Avro definition should look like:

`{"type": "fixed", "name": "128bit", "size": 16}`

title: [SPOT-278] Changes to ReadMe
body:
- Removed references to Slack
- Added references to dev Mailing list
- Revised Merge approval section to give more details on the steps necessary.

title: [SPOT-277] Updates to Spot Website
body:
I've made a couple of updates to the Apache Spot Website on the ASF-Site branch.
1) I've removed all references to Slack
2) I've added links to the Confluence website

There's a new folder called "_Tools". It just contains a python script I used to help me perform the updates faster.

title: [SPOT-276] Update odm_setup.sh
body: Example for format argument usage corrected.

body:
Hi there,

PR #128 introduced a portable path to bash. This PR extends #128 and fixes the hardcoded path to bash when being called by `screen`.

Cheers,
tpltnt

title: Ingestion using Spark Streaming
body:
## Ingestion using Spark Streaming
A new branch of Spot Ingest framework, where ingestion via Spark Streaming [**Spark2**] is available for flow, dns and proxy. The code was developed without modifying the existing one, to provide this feature as an extra  functionality. This means that the current functionality of the Spot Ingest framework still exists and the **Streaming Ingestion** can be used **as an alternative**.

### Implementation
A new collector class [**Distributed Collector**] has been added, which is the same for all pipelines. The role of the Distributed Collector is similar, as it processes the data before transmission. Distributed Collector tracks a directory backwards for newly created files. When a file is detected, it converts it into CSV format and stores the output in the local staging area. Following to that, reads the CSV file line-by-line and creates smaller chunks of bytes. The size of each chunk depends on the maximum request size allowed by Kafka. Finally, it serializes each chunk into an Avro-encoded format and publishes them to Kafka cluster.
Due to its architecture, Distributed Collector can run **on an edge node** of the Big Data infrastructure as well as **on a remote host** (proxy server, vNSF, etc).
Distributed Collector publishes to Apache Kafka only the CSV-converted file, and not the original one. The binary file remains to the local filesystem of the current host.

In contrary, **Streaming Listener** can only run on the central infrastructure. Its ability is to listen to a specific Kafka topic and consumes incoming messages. Streaming data is divided into batches (according to a time interval). These batches are deserialized by the Listener, according to the supported Avro schema, parsed and registered in the corresponding table of Hive.

For each pipeline, the following modules have been implemented:
*  **processing** - contains methods that will be used to convert and prepare ingested data, before being sent to Kafka cluster.
* **streaming** - contains methods to be used during the streaming process (like table schema etc.).

### Advantages
A preliminary traffic ingestion check for all pipelines (flow,dns,proxy) of the distributed collector-worker modules has been applied on an existing Spot v1.0 installation. In a summary, the module has flawless performance on netflow files (both .nfcapd and .csv), order of **magnitude quicker** compared to standard version's ingestion. DNS and proxy ingestion were tested as well with similar results.

title: [SPOT-269] odm event schema updates
body:
# Proposed new fields:
Common
- session_id (string)
- length (int)

Device
- dvc_mac (string)

Network
- src_mac (string)
- dst_mac (string
- src_tos (string)
- dst_tos (string)

File
- file_uid (string)

Flow
- flow_fwd_status (string)
- flow_snmp_in (string)
- flow_snmp_out (string)

Agent (New)
- agent_severity (string)
- agent_mac (string)
- agent_time (bigint)
- agent_id (string)
- agent_description (string)
- agent_type (string)
- agent_ip4 (bigint)
- agent_ip4_str (string)
- agent_ip6 (string)
- agent_ip6_str (string)
- agent_host (string)

# Proposed fields to type change:
- http_response_resp_fuids (string) -> (array<string>)
- tls_cert_chain_fuids (string) -> (array<string>)
- tls_client_cert_chain_fuids string) -> (array<string>)

## Reason for changes to ip6 fields - Inability to store 128bit integers as 'bigint' type fields.  For now ip6 fields will be stored as strings.

- dvc_ip6 (bigint) -> (string)
- dvc_fwd_ip6 (bigint) -> (string)
- src_ip6 (bigint) -> (string)
- dst_ip6 (bigint) -> (string)

title: SPOT-261. ODM event schema additional_attrs field should be map<string>
body: The Avro and Parquet table schemas designate the additional_attrs field as a map<string, string>, but in the Avro schema definition (in event.avsc), the field is listed as just an optional string. This field should be updated to be an optional map<string>

1. Backed out changes to spot-oa ([SPOT-180](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-180) changes for OA should happen in a separate PR)

These updates should leave spot-ml in a good state (whether merging into SPOT-180_ODM or master), until ODM source data is available from Hive.

title: [SPOT-213] Kerberos support and compatibility
body:
Unfortunately this is against my normal better judgement to include such a large PR.
However for things to work you must have the complete package.
Although there are areas of small change that could have been incremental over 90% of it would still need to be there.

Although normally there would be more atomic commits, the commit history is quite large.
I've tried to provide some modular commits for better readability through the review process

Please see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-213 for the list of jira's

The goal here is to support Kerberos and SSL.
This I done via the addition of the spot.conf configuration changes.

Although there still need to be a couple of changes to completely drop all CLI tools, Impyla and the python hdfs client have been used in place of most of them here. providing some more flexibility in where you run code.

title: SPOT-249. Update Windows Event Log ingest to support SDC Edge
body: This updates the ODMWindowsEventLogs pipeline to consume off of an HTTP Server origin, which will receive data from an SDC Edge pipeline sending System, Security, or Application logs over an HTTP connection. This is intended as a configurable starting point, as there will likely be additional customization required for any real-world environment. SDC does not easily run on Windows, so SDC Edge will allow offload of Windows logs to an SDC pipeline that delivers data into the ODM schema. Windows to HTTP: HTTP Server to ODM:

title: SPOT-245. StreamSets pipeline for NetFlow data into ODM
body: This adds a starter config for using StreamSets to ingest NetFlow data into the ODM, as well as legacy Parquet tables. It's primarily designed for NetFlow v9, but should support NetFlow v5, as well.

title: Spot 234 odm field and avro schema fixes
body:
The scope of this PR includes the following improvements and fixes:
- Fix "user_image" field type in pqt and avro User Context create table statement. Binary is not a supported Impala type. Also fixed naming issue in pqt table where "user_image" is currently named "user_img".
- Fix all avro schemas to use primitive types in schema literals. Complex types are not queryable in Impala. Any array or map types will be converted to String types in the avro literals.

title: Incorrect assumption inbound/outbound crashes
body:
The code assumes that there are always inbound only and outbound only connections. This causes saving a scored threat that has either no inbound, or outbound only connections. Fix is simply moving the column header row to outside the check, so the array element is always initialized before being accessed.

Tested the following case
a) Inbound and Twoway only
b) Outbound only
c) Outbound and twoway only

title: SPOT-233 Sample Arcadia Dashboards for ODM
body: "spot_app.json" is a configuration file containing all of the current sample Apache Spot dashboards. The current set of sample Apache Spot dashboards include: Network Activity, User Activity Summary, User Activity Details, Endpoint Activity Summary, Endpoint Activity Details, and Vulnerabilities views. Details about each of these dashboards can be found in the README along with installation instructions and sources for sample data. This file can be imported into either Arcadia Instant or Enterprise. ODM tables should be setup before importing the configuration file. Once imported the dashboards will align with the ODM tables that have been set up.

title: SPOT-230 Open Data Model (ODM) Setup
body: This PR contains the  necessary scripts and statements to construct the Open Data Model (ODM) as specified in the ODM document. There are currently 6 tables that are provided in the ODM: event, user_context, endpoint_context, network_context, threat_intelligence_context, and vulnerability context. The details and schemas for each of these can be found in the ODM document. Both Parquet and Avro storage options are available when building the tables.  The tables are built using the odm_setup.sh script found in this PR, which requires a format argument to be passed in (i.e. ./odm_setup.sh pqt OR ./odm_setup.sh avro).  A README is also included as a reference guide for anyone look to setup the ODM tables.

title: [SPOT-216] hdfs_setup.sh additions to support hive  + some tweaks
body:
First stage in [#SPOT-216](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPOT-216)

## file changes:
* split the HQL scripts by database application hive scripts to ./hive/ and impala scripts to ./impala/ etc

## spot.conf
* added DBENGINE to preselect hive cli, impala cli, or beeline with JDBC url
* added JDBC_URL (tested with kerberos)

## hdfs_setup.sh:
* added `set -e` to stop on errors
* using case to parse options
* added --no-sudo to control rather `sudo -u hdfs hdfs ...` is used or `hdfs` in addition to the $HADOOP_USER_NAME field *kept this safe so that you can set the env var prior to running*
* added `-c /some/location/for/spot.conf` as an option to use custom locations. This is intended to make it easier for test&dev
* logic to use `DBENGINE='hive' # hive,impala supported`
* added `-d [hive,impala,beeline]` option to hdfs_setup.sh
* using some functions to keep from having errors from existing folders. this is mainly due to cases where an error occurred and the script was re-run.

## *.hql scripts:
* added `IF NOT EXISTS` to create table commands

title: Spot 181 odm
body:
There are some inconsistencies in the open data model descriptions:
- There are _long_ and _bigint_ types for timestamps.
- Ipv4 addresses are declared as _long_ but _int_ is enough.
- Ipv6 addresses are declared as _bigint_.
- http info status are explicitly declared as _http_info_status_ when it is just a specific case of _http_code_status_.

Here is a modified version of the open data model trying to fix the previous inconsitencies. Following avro types I have used:
- _int_ for 32bit
- _long_ for 64bit.
Avro does not have a type for 128bit. I have use _int128_ as type definition for the ODM. Avro definition should look like:
` {"type": "fixed", "name": "128bit", "size": 16}`

title: Spot-196 [ML] Spot LDA Wrapper refactoring
body:
Implement changes requested on **SPOT-196**. Decouples SpotLDAWrapper functionality in preparation for next steps of spot-ml including plans for near real-time. 

### Main changes
Refactored SpotLDAWrapper into new objects/classes in order to support further uses of spot-ml and/or new applications.

The current implementation supports only training a model and getting topicsMatrix + topicDistributions in the format Spot ML requires it for scoring. Two new features are added:

1. Ability to save a model and load an existing model
2. Ability to predict new documents using OnlineLDAOptimizer

New objects: 
- _SpotLDAHelper_: Receives and RDD with document word count information and the floating point precision users want to use for training and getting results. The object will offer a method to return the corpus formatted for Spark LDA and internally will generate a dictionary of Document -> id and Word -> id. 
Given the document and word dictionary, SpotLDAHelper offers a method to return topic distributions formatted for Spot scoring (IP -> [Topic distribution]). Also, offers a method to return the word probability (Word -> [Topic probaility]). 
- _SpotLDAModel_: It's a wrapper for EM based and Online based models. Depending on the optimizer, the prediction method can be used with a new set of documents (wrapped in a new SpotLDAHelper) or it will be using the same SpotLDAHelper (developers should simply pass the same SpotLDAHelper object used for training). It also exposes a method to save the model in HDFS.
- _SpotLDAResults_: This object will concentrate topic distributions as they are predicted from the LDA Model + the formatted version for Spot scoring, the topics matrix result from training and the corresponding version formatted for spot scoring.

Updated objects:
-SpotLDAWrapper: This object was modified so it just executes the model training and returns a new SpotLDAModel which can be either Distributed or Local LDA Model. It also exposes a new method for just loading an existing model. 

### Other changes
- Updated DNSSuspiciousConnectsModel, FlowSuspiciousConnectsModel, and ProxySuspiciousConnectsModel as well as the corresponding unit test to implement the new SpotLDAWrapper and related objects.
- Small code refactoring to TopDomains, removed an unused variable.

### Extra notes

1. Developers should understand when and how to use EM based model vs Online based model:
EM = Use it for batch processing, only when it's possible or required to train and score with the same set of documents (current implementation).
Online = The choice for near real time actually. Use it for batch processing if required or for training a model and loading later to predict **based on a new set of documents**.
2. During the test of these changes, the team discovered that Spark LDA DataFrame based is not ready yet neither for batch mode or near real time when using EM optimizer since it reduces precision predicting topic distributions.

title: SPOT-183 Schema validation for input data
body:
This PR implements changes requested in SPOT-183 and aims to overpass issues reported on SPOT-174 and SPOT-149. It validates input dataset (reading dataframe schema) and checks if it contains the schema required for model training.

#### Main changes

- Added schema validation based on columns required for model training.

- Updated each pipeline (DNS, Flow, Proxy) so the schema is validated before performing any other activity.

- Updated main activity to show error about bad schema if any.

- The main application now will print what fields are not matching the expected schema.

- Added unit test for schema validation.
